full_text: In this demonstration, you will see how the payment plan controls the way BillingCenter slices a premium charge into installments and places them on invoices. Here's Kerb Smith's account. I'm going to open the policy issuance wizard to quickly add a policy with a premium charge. I select Add Policy from the Actions menu. This time I'll create a Homeowners policy. Let's give it a policy number. I select Homeowners as the product. I'll use the same payment plan that we used in the previous demo. Here's PP07. I select it. Let's move on to step 2. I click Add to create the premium charge. The amount of the charge is $1,804. I type in the amount. And click Finish. We're back at the account summary. Let's take a look at the charge first. I click Charges in the sidebar. The premium charge is listed at the top of the screen. Below the charge, it's easy to see the 25% down payment in the 11 installments that resulted from the charge. How did the down payment and first installment end up on the same invoice? The answer is, Look at the invoice bill date of the first invoice. Now look at the placement dates of the down payment item and the first installment item. Both invoice items have placement dates that are on or before the invoice bill date. Let's look at the invoices. The first invoice has both the down payment and first installment. Looking at the second invoice, we see just one installment. In fact, all of the remaining invoices have one installment invoice item for the same amount. Let's look at the invoice stream. The periodicity is monthly. The Override Day of Month field specifies the anchor date for the invoice stream. The anchor date came from the payment plan. Let's revisit the payment plan. From the Administration tab menu, I select Payment Plans from the Business Settings menu. The payment plan is PP07. We can see the down payment can be invoiced as early as 25 days before the charge date. The first installment will be invoiced 10 days after the charge date. This explains the difference in placement dates between the down payment and first installment items. Is there a way to ensure that the down payment and first installment land on different invoices? The answer is, yes, there is. This topic is covered next in the lesson. This concludes our demonstration on invoicing a premium charge. of the                   of the of the   of the      of the      of the     of the   of the           of the  Thank you.

segments.text: In this demonstration, you will see how the payment plan controls the way BillingCenter slices a premium charge into installments and places them on invoices. Here's Kerb Smith's account. I'm going to open the policy issuance wizard to quickly add a policy with a premium charge. I select Add Policy from the Actions menu. This time I'll create a Homeowners policy. Let's give it a policy number.

I select Homeowners as the product. I'll use the same payment plan that we used in the previous demo. Here's PP07. I select it. Let's move on to step 2. I click Add to create the premium charge. The amount of the charge is $1,804.

I type in the amount. And click Finish. We're back at the account summary. Let's take a look at the charge first. I click Charges in the sidebar. The premium charge is listed at the top of the screen. Below the charge, it's easy to see the 25% down payment in the 11 installments that resulted from the charge. How did the down payment and first installment end up on the same invoice? The answer is,

Look at the invoice bill date of the first invoice. Now look at the placement dates of the down payment item and the first installment item. Both invoice items have placement dates that are on or before the invoice bill date.

Let's look at the invoices. The first invoice has both the down payment and first installment. Looking at the second invoice, we see just one installment. In fact, all of the remaining invoices have one installment invoice item for the same amount. Let's look at the invoice stream.
The periodicity is monthly. The Override Day of Month field specifies the anchor date for the
invoice stream. The anchor date came from the payment plan. Let's revisit the payment plan.
From the Administration tab menu, I select Payment Plans from the Business Settings menu.
The payment plan is PP07. We can see the down payment can be invoiced as early as 25 days
before the charge date. The first installment will be invoiced 10 days after the charge date.
This explains the difference in placement dates between the down payment and first installment items.
Is there a way to ensure that the down payment and first installment land on different invoices?
The answer is, yes, there is. This topic is covered next in the lesson.
This concludes our demonstration on invoicing a premium charge.
